entry.title: Migrating Point-to-Point Asynchronous Scenarios Using the Migration Tool in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
This blog post is part of the series Master Blog: SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite Migration ‚Äì Tool and Guidance exploring how to migrate various integration patterns from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite using the Migration Tool. In this blog, we will focus on the Point-to-Point (P2P) Asynchronous pattern, which is one of the most common and fundamental integration scenarios.

 

Objective

The goal of this blog is to explain how the Migration Tool supports P2P asynchronous integrations, including:

  • Key configuration options and technical considerations
  • Best practices to ensure reliable and decoupled communication
  • How to implement JMS decoupling and Idempotent Processing effectively

 

Understanding the Point-to-Point Asynchronous Pattern

In a Point-to-Point (P2P) asynchronous integration, a message is sent from a sender to a receiver without a response message. This pattern promotes decoupling between systems, improves reliability, and allows retry mechanisms to ensure delivery in case you are using JMS queues. By default, the Migration Tool will enable JMS queues during migration.

If there are constraints on the limit of available JMS queues, the tool also supports direct communication without JMS, though this reduces decoupling and resilience. If you are migrating a high number of asynchronous interfaces, SAP recommends using the pipeline approach, which will not be covered in this blog. You can find more information in Pipeline Concept and  Migration Tooling now supporting migration via the pipeline approach.

 

Migration Tool Support for P2P Asynchronous Scenarios using Standard Approach

The Migration Tool automates most of the effort by generating a ready-to-use Integration Flow (iFlow) and the corresponding configuration objects in SAP Cloud Integration.

Depending on your settings, the tool can generate Integration Flows that:

1. Decouple with JMS Queue: Use JMS queues for decoupling between sender and receiver systems (only shown for Asynchronous interfaces):

When you select this option, the Migration Tool creates two Integration Processes within the generated iFlow:

  • Inbound Process
    • Receives the message from the migrated Sender Component and Communication Channel
    • Forwards the message to the JMS queue
  • Outbound Process
    • Reads the message from the JMS queue
    • Performs any required processing (e.g., message mapping, data transformation)

Delivers the message to the receiver system

Please note that you need to maintain the name of the JMS queue post-migration using the already created external parameters:

2. Idempotent Process at the Receiver Side: Use the idempotent process call if you want to make sure that the message will be delivered exactly once to the target system:

When you select this option, the generated iFlow will include an Idempotent Process Call. This mechanism ensures that a message is delivered exactly once to the receiver system, avoiding duplicate postings.

The API call at the receiver system is wrapped then into this local integration process.

There are receiver adapters that do supports idempotency such as SOAP RM, XI and IDoc. In these cases, it‚Äôs preferable that you don‚Äôt use the Idempotent option on Migration Tool and choose to handle it directly in the adapter. You can find more information in Special Use Cases: SAP RM vs XI vs IDoc.

 

Post-Migration Activities and Special Scenarios

While the Migration Tool significantly accelerates the transition from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite, a few manual fine-tuning steps are typically required.

Generic Post-Migration Steps

After migrating a P2P Asynchronous interface:

  1. Review and update external parameters for sender and receiver connectivity.
  2. Define the JMS queue name to be used in both Integration Processes (in case checkbox is marked during wizard). This can be done in the external parameters‚Äô configuration view.
  3. Update
  4. Review if you want to change the value of the header SAP_Sender according to the naming convention that will be adopted on SAP Integration Suite.

Manual Activities Depending on Integration Scenario

You can also find below few examples of manual activities post-migration that needs to be performed depending on the content of your integration scenario:

  1. Functions like RFC Lookup or JDBC Lookup on Graphical Message Mapping are not automatically converted. Replace them with equivalent Integration Suite adapters or externalized APIs. Tutorials are available for JDBC lookups and RFC lookups.
  2. If your interface is using any custom code (e.g., UDF, Function Library, Java Mapping) or XSLT that have additional dependencies, Therefore, you need to export them from SAP Process Orchestration and import into your Integration Flow
  3. If your interface is using a fault message handling, this won‚Äôt be migrated using the Migration Tool. Therefore, you need to import the mapping using the standalone functionality and add an exception handling subprocess into the migrated iFlow

Please refer to the Known Limitations of Migration Tooling for additional insights into cases that may require manual adjustments after migration. we will explore specific topics in more depth, such as XSLT transformation differences between SAP Process Orchestration and SAP Integration Suite, custom code migration, fault message handling, and other advanced migration scenarios.

 

Async-Sync Bridge Support

The Point-to-Point Asynchronous pattern also covers scenarios using an Async-Sync bridge.

In SAP Process Orchestration, an asynchronous interface is converted into synchronous using the RequestResponseBean module, enabling a response message to be sent back to the sender asynchronously using a second interface object.

The Migration Tool can migrate this Async-Sync bridge scenario as well, ensuring that both asynchronous and synchronous steps are merged into a single iFlow.

Please note that the Sync-Async bridge scenario (the opposite from the above), is not supported as of today.

 

Conclusion

In this first blog of the blog series, we explored how to migrate Point-to-Point Asynchronous scenarios and how the Migration Tool simplifies this process by leveraging JMS decoupling and Idempotent Processing. These capabilities help ensure reliable, scalable, and fault-tolerant communication between systems.

entry.title: Java Integration Failures After SAP BTP‚Äôs DigiCert G5 Root Certificate Adoption ‚Äì A Practical Fix
entry.content:
Background

Around seven days ago, SAP replaced its old root certificate, DigiCert Global Root G2, with DigiCert Global Root G5. This change was part of a regular security renewal on SAP‚Äôs side ‚Äî but it caught many Java based applications off guard.

Operating system level trust stores were updated in line with instructions received. But...
While browsers and Windows applications updated their trust automatically, Java runtimes did not.
That‚Äôs where things got interesting.

The Symptom

One of our external systems, running on Red Hat OpenJDK ‚Äî suddenly stopped sending messages to SAP ECC via BTP Integration Suite.

The log showed this familiar (but dreaded) exception:

 
javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: PKIX path building failed: sun.security.provider.certpath.SunCertPathBuilderException: unable to find valid certification path to requested target

Classic SSL trust failure ‚Äî and in this case, caused by a missing root certificate.

The Analysis

The new DigiCert Global Root G5 certificate was trusted by Windows but missing in the OpenJDK truststore (cacerts).

Unlike browsers or OS components, this particular JRE maintains its own internal truststore ‚Äî it doesn‚Äôt inherit the operating system‚Äôs trusted certificate authorities.

So while everything else trusted the new SAP certificate, the Java runtime didn‚Äôt recognize it ‚Äî and refused to connect.

The Practical Fix

1Ô∏è‚É£ Backup the existing truststore

cd <path_to_redhat_openjdk>\jre\lib\security copy cacerts cacerts.bak

2Ô∏è‚É£ Download the DigiCert Global Root G5 certificate

Get it directly from DigiCert‚Äôs official repository:
https://knowledge.digicert.com/generalinformation/digicert-root-and-intermediate-ca-certificates

Save it as g5.cer.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Import the certificate into Java‚Äôs truststore

..\..\bin\keytool -importcert -file g5.cer -keystore cacerts -alias "DigiCertG5" 

Default password: changeit
Confirm when prompted.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Verify the import

..\..\bin\keytool -list -keystore cacerts -storepass changeit | find "DigiCertG5"

5Ô∏è‚É£ Restart your application

Restart any Java processes using that truststore.

‚úÖ Result: SSL handshake succeeded.
‚úÖ Message flow from JAVA APP ‚Üí BTP IS ‚Üí SAP ECC restored.

 

Lessons Learned

  1. Java ‚â† Browser.
    Java doesn‚Äôt automatically inherit trusted roots from your OS.

  2. Certificate renewals ripple.
    Cloud platforms like SAP BTP periodically renew CAs ‚Äî and your Java apps might silently fail afterward.

  3. Test from the runtime, not Chrome.
    Always validate SSL using the same Java runtime your integration runs on.

  4. Keep a ‚Äútrust refresh‚Äù procedure.
    Maintain a documented, repeatable way to update and verify truststores.

  5. Automate where possible. If you manage multiple runtimes, script the import and verification steps.

 

The Bigger Picture

Integration is all about trust ‚Äî both technically and organizationally.
A single missing certificate can bring down a perfectly built integration chain.

This incident was a reminder: even when nothing changes in your code, something always changes in the environment. And sometimes, that enough to break trust.

entry.title: Lifecycle Management enhancements you don‚Äôt want to miss in SAP Business One SP 2511 !
entry.content:
If you administrate SAP Business One systems or handle lifecycle management operations - this one‚Äôs for you !

The latest Support Package (SP 2511) brings meaningful upgrades across Lifecycle Management, strengthening identity management, refining security, and simplifying system operations.

Here‚Äôs a quick roundup of what‚Äôs new:

Identity & Authentication Management (IAM)

The Identity and Authentication Management guide now includes two key updates designed to make authentication more seamless and secure:

  • Principal Propagation via Azure Apps
    SAP Business One now supports authentication of user context coming from Microsoft Azure based applications. The propagated identity is securely passed into SAP Business One, allowing partner applications to access system resources without additional sign-ins. 
    üìñ  To learn more about Principal Propagation via Azure Apps, refer to this chapter under Identity and Authentication Management guide
  • Single Sign-On with AD FS
    Ever wished you could sign in to the Web Client using your Windows SSO?
    Users with Active Directory Federation Service (AD FS) accounts can now enable SSO by configuring browsers to use Windows Integrated Authentication, making the login experience faster and frictionless. 
    üìñ  For step-by-step instructions, see the dedicated     chapter under Identity and Authentication Management guide



Server Tools: Dedicated Tomcat Instances
As the saying goes, ‚ÄúGood things come in small packages"...In this case, separating Tomcat instances means smoother restarts, fewer conflicts, and a faster SAP Business One backend.
SP 2511 introduces a modular Tomcat architecture for core components, allowing each service to be restarted or redeployed independently for greater flexibility and uptime.
Here's the breakdown for component configuration in SP 2511:

  • For SAP Business One (MS SQL)

    Component / ServiceDefault Port Description
    SAP Business One Server Tools Service (64-bit)40000

    Hosts System Landscape Directory (SLD) and Extension Manager 

    SAP Business One License Service (64-bit)40002Dedicated Instance for License Service
    SAP Business One Job Service (64-bit)40004Runs Job Service (and embedded MS365 Integration)
    ‚ÑπÔ∏è   You need to update the redirect URI for Microsoft 365 Integration after upgrading SAP Business One to 10.0 SP 2511 as Microsoft 365 Integration is installed with Job Service.
    SAP Business One Service Layer Controller (64-bit)40005Runs Mobile Service and Service Layer Configuration Manager
    ‚ÑπÔ∏è  This change applies exclusively to the Service Layer Configuration Manager. The port numbers for the Service Layer Load Balancer and Service Layer Nodes remain unchanged

  • For SAP Business One (Version for HANA)

    Component / ServiceDefault Port Description
    sapb1servertools.service40000

    Hosts System Landscape Directory (SLD), Extension Manager and Backup Service

    sapb1servertools-license.service40002Dedicated Instance for License Service
    sapb1servertools-analytics.service
    		40003Runs Analytics Service
    sapb1servertools-jobservice.service40004Runs Job Service (and embedded MS365 Integration)
    ‚ÑπÔ∏è   You need to update the redirect URI for Microsoft 365 Integration after upgrading SAP Business One to 10.0 SP 2511 as Microsoft 365 Integration is installed with Job Service.
    sapb1servertools-servicelayercontroller.service40005Runs Mobile Service and Service Layer Configuration Manager
    ‚ÑπÔ∏è  This change applies exclusively to the Service Layer Configuration Manager. The port numbers for the Service Layer Load Balancer and Service Layer Nodes remain unchanged

‚ÑπÔ∏è  Note:
During installation (or upgrade from versions earlier than SP 2511), port numbers can be configured directly in the setup wizard via dedicated panes or during reconfigure.
Make sure to review and adjust your network, firewall, and high-availability settings to match the new port configuration.
(As part of this restructuring, the default port for License Manager and License Control Center is updated from 40000 to 40002.
Administrators configuring high availability need to adjust settings to ensure seamless integration with the new setup).



Platform Matrix Updates
Here's what's new under supported Matrix for SAP Business One (MSSQL and Version for HANA):

Newly supported:

  • Microsoft Windows Server 2025
  • SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 15 SP7 (x86_64)
  • SAP HANA Enterprise Edition 2.0 SPS 08 Revision 087 (SAP HANA Client Version 2.25.31)

No longer supported:

  • SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 15 SP4 

‚ÑπÔ∏è  Note: 
SAP Business One Cloud 1.1 PL21 doesn‚Äôt support SAP HANA Enterprise Edition 2.0 SPS 08 Revision 087.



Security Hardening
(Applicable for users that log in to SAP Business One with a company user account - not an IDP account).

By now, you‚Äôve probably noticed the "Refresh"  button under the "Choose/Create Company"  window is gone and you might be wondering why. The reason is simple: it‚Äôs all about keeping things safe and controlled!

Here's how it works; If a company database is restored directly on the database server (outside of SAP Business One), it‚Äôs now up to the Landscape administrator to refresh the company list centrally via System Landscape Directory (SLD). This ensures that only authorized users can make newly restored companies visible under "Choose/Create Company"  window, reducing unnecessary exposure of system information before users are authenticated.

Internal operations triggered from within SAP Business One, such as company creation, upgrades, or year-end transfers, automatically refresh the company list as part of the workflow, so no additional action required in these scenarios.



Summary

SP 2511 brings smarter IAM, a more flexible modular Tomcat setup, expanded platform support, and tighter security for company databases - all designed to make managing SAP Business One smoother, safer, and more effective in your day-to-day operations.

Thanks for reading this roundup of SP 2511 lifecycle management updates! Hope you find these features valuable and enjoy putting them to work in your daily operations.

entry.title: Re: Unplanned Delivery Cost of Purchasing in S4HANA Cloud, Public Edition
entry.content:
@Qi_Liu  Thanks, Our customer requires that freight (unplanned delivery cost) is handled via a separate purchase order, so the freight supplier receives a distinct PO document. For materials managed at moving average price (MAP) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, how can we link the freight PO and resulting invoice to the original goods PO/material so the freight cost updates the material‚Äôs MAP, rather than posting only to an expense account? Is there a standard configuration or process for this scenario or any practical workaround? Detailed steps or best-practice recommendations would be highly appreciated. Thank you!

As a workaround, we tried the following approach: within the same international purchase order, we created a freight condition type and entered an approximate freight value. We then changed the supplier accordingly.

To handle document printing without confusion, we developed two separate print forms:

International PO ‚Äì for the main material supplier

Local Freight PO ‚Äì for the freight supplier

With this setup, the landed cost was correctly added to the material‚Äôs moving average price (MAP) after the goods receipt.

However, when attempting to post the invoice for the freight supplier, we were unable to adjust the amount to match the actual freight charges. As a result, the unplanned delivery cost was not added to the material, and the system returned an error message (attached below).

I need urgent help with my SAP Learning Hub Student Edition activation. I've followed all the standard procedures but my practice systems remain locked.

  • Saturday, November 8, 2025 (3:55 PM): Received verification email confirming "Your university status has been successfully verified"

  • Monday, November 10, 2025 (current): Still no access to practice systems despite waiting the stated "one business day"

Steps I've Already Taken:

  1. ‚úÖ Successfully verified my university status (have confirmation email)

  2. ‚úÖ Waited the full business day as instructed

  3. ‚úÖ Opened a support case (they responded but just told me to wait)

  4. ‚úÖ Tried contacting support directly (was told to use the case system)

  5. ‚úÖ Cleared browser cache, tried different browsers

  6. ‚úÖ Checked spam folder for activation emails

Current Issue:

  • Practice systems show as locked when I try to access them

  • No follow-up activation email received

  • Support case is open but hasn't resolved the issue

  • This is urgently needed for my coursework/studies

System Details:

  • Using SAP Learning Hub Student Edition (free version)

  • Browser: Chrome (latest version)

  • Location: GMT timezone

Questions:

  1. Is there a known delay with weekend verifications being processed on Monday?

  2. Should I have received a second email after the verification?

  3. Is there a way to escalate my existing support case for urgent academic needs?

I would greatly appreciate any guidance from the community or SAP moderators. This is blocking my ability to complete urgent academic work.

Thank you in advance for your help!

entry.title: Enabling external workflow for Features in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
We are thrilled to introduce the integration of external workflow for Features in SAP Cloud ALM! It is our newest Change and Deployment Management functionality designed to add custom approval and confirmation steps to the default Feature workflow.

With Feature workflow integration, you can automatically trigger a custom workflow when a Feature‚Äôs status changes to ‚ÄòSuccessfully Tested". Custom workflows can be created using external workflow tools, such as SAP Build Process Automation.

In the following example, we will show how to design a custom test confirmation workflow in SAP Build Process Automation (BPA) and enable it for Features in SAP Cloud ALM. When the user triggers the action "Confirm Successful Test" in a Feature, the workflow is automatically started in the BPA instance. A test confirmation request will be sent to the inbox of the dedicated approver. If the request is approved, the Feature status will be set to "Successfully Tested". In case the request is rejected,  the Feature status will stay "In Testing".

Configuration Prerequisites

  • SAP Build Process Automation subscription and the corresponding service instance (including service key) are available.

For more information, please see: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-process-automation/sap-build-process-automation/subscribe-to-sap-build-process-automation

  • SAP Cloud ALM has been provisioned and a Cloud ALM API service instance has been created (including service key)

For more information on how to create a Cloud ALM API service instance, please see: Enabling SAP Cloud ALM API 

Configuration Overview

  • Create destination from SAP Cloud ALM to SAP Build Process Automation
  • Create destination from SAP Build Process Automation to SAP Cloud ALM
  • Define workflow in SAP Build Process Automation
  • Create workflow subscription in SAP Cloud ALM
  • Assign the workflow subscription to a project in SAP Cloud ALM

Create destination from SAP Cloud ALM to SAP Build Process Automation

Logon to your SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) subaccount where your SAP Cloud ALM tenant is provisioned. Navigate to the section Connectivity -> Destinations and create a destination with the following parameter:

Parameter Name Value
Type HTTP
URL https://<url>/workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances
<url> = URL from the section endpoints -> api of the BPA instance service key
Proxy Type Internet
Authentication OAuth2ClientCredentials
Client ID section uaa->clientid of the BPA instance service key
Client Secret section uaa->clientsecret of the BPA instance service key
Token Service URL Typededicated
Token Service URLhttps://<tenant>.authentication.<domain>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
for <tenant> and <domain>, please refer to the URL from the section uaa->url of the BPA instance service key

 Create destination from SAP Build Process Automation to SAP Cloud ALM

Logon to your SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) subaccount where your SAP Build Process Automation tenant is provisioned. Navigate to the section Connectivity -> Destinations and create a destination with the following parameter:

Parameter Name Value
Type HTTP
URL https://<your tenant>/api
Proxy Type Internet
Authentication OAuth2ClientCredentials
Client ID section uaa->clientid of the Cloud ALM API instance service key
Client Secret section uaa->clientsecret of the Cloud ALM API instance service key
Token Service URL Typededicated
Token Service URLhttps://<tenant>.authentication.<domain>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
for <tenant> and <domain>, please refer to the URL from the section uaa->url of the Cloud ALM API instance service key

Add the following additional properties to the destination:

  • sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled = true
  • sap.processautomation.enabled = true

Define workflow in SAP Build Process Automation

Here is an example of a test confirmation workflow including a 4-eyes principle check and email notification to the test approvers:

You can download the example workflow HERE, import it into your SAP Build Process Automation tenant and adjust it to your needs.

Note, that the Feature status switch is done by using the Workflow API. When a workflow is accepted (workflow status COMPLETED), the Feature status will be set to "Successfully Tested". In case a workflow is rejected (workflow status FAILED), the Feature status will remain "In Testing". By using script tasks you can access the contextual information of the workflow and maintain optional attributes like externalApprovers or externalDecision which are maintained in the Feature history when a workflow is executed.

For more information about script tasks, please check the following: https://help.sap.com/docs/workflow-capability/workflow-cloud-foundry/accessing-contextual-information-during-execution-of-script-tasks 

Please ensure that you have created an environment variable of type Destination under the project properties of your workflow project:

At the project deployment you will be asked to map the Cloud ALM API destination (from SAP Build Process Automation to Cloud ALM) to the destination variable:

Create workflow subscription in SAP Cloud ALM

Create a webhook in External API Management

Logon to your SAP Cloud ALM tenant and navigate to External API Management:

Go to Webhooks Management and choose ‚ÄúAdd new webhook‚Äù:

Enter the following data:

Parameter Name Value
Name<name of the webhook>
Ext Resource TypeWorkflow
Destination SourceBTP destination
Destination Id <id of the destination from SAP Cloud ALM to Build Process Automation tenant>
Destination Type Other

Create mapping

Go to Mappings Management and choose "Add new mapping":

Enter the following data:

Parameter Name Value
Description<name of the mapping>
Version1.0
SourceSAP Cloud ALM
Destination SAP Build Process Automation
Mapping TypePayload Based

Download the example mapping HERE and use it to define the mapping rules.

For more information about mandatory and optional mapping, please check the corresponding sections of the Feature Workflow API guide: https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/apis/configuration-steps-for-workflow-api-for-features 

Add a subscription in External API Management

Go to Subscriptions Management and choose ‚ÄúAdd new subscription‚Äù.

Enter the following data:

Parameter Name Value
Name<name of the subscription>
Description<description of the subscription>
TypeBuilt-in
Resource TypeWorkflow
Webhook <name of the webhook you created before>
Mapping <name of the mapping you created before>
User Variable NameworkflowDefinitionId
User Variable Value<workflow id>

To get the workflow ID, logon to your SAP Build Process Automation tenant, navigate to Control Tower and go to the tile Environments. Choose the environment where you deployed your workflow. Go to Processes and Workflows, choose your workflow and copy the ID:

This is how the example subscription looks like:

Assign the workflow subscription to a project in SAP Cloud ALM

Navigate to a project for which you want to use the Feature workflow and go to the Subscriptions tab. Assign the already created workflow subscription to the Feature entity:

You are now able to execute test confirmations for Features in SAP Cloud ALM by using SAP Build Process Automation.

entry.title: Re: Effortless SAPUI5 Patch Management: Introducing the New SAPUI5 Runtime Repository
entry.content:
@Marian_Zeis 
Those questions are difficult to answer and first a big disclaimer:
The following is not an official roadmap and you cannot derive any promises or guarantees for the future. Plans are subject to change!

To start with what is possible right now:

  • You will never be able to specify a minor or patch version to run with. Trying this on the ABAP stack, is not supported or allowed
  • There is no SAPUI5 2.0 available, that could be installed at all.

Therefore the answer to all questions is currently: No

Now about the future:

  • There might be a SAPUI5 2.0, which would then be installed on the ABAP system
  • The bootstrap URL from which the UI5 runtime is served can be enhanced with one segment specifying the major version. This can then be used for apps outside FLP in their bootstrap tag.
  • The schema of the manifest.json has already been enhanced that sap.ui5/dependencies/minUI5Version can be an array, specifying multiple min versions, one per supported major version. I.e. apps can express which major versions they support.
  • In FLP it would be up to the system to decide which runtime version is used, based on the specified supported major versions. 

I do not know what you mean with the last question. Could you clarify this?
In general a major version switch is an incompatible change and apps must be ready for this. I.e. there can't be a global setting which affects all apps at once.

entry.title: SAPUI5 application in Build Workzone with CAP Application as a proxy to the backend returns 403
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I have a scenario that seems to be quite common, but I'm failing to find why exactly the integration between the SAPUI5 and a CAP microsservice is not working. In what follows there are some details:

  • I have a CAP application with an approuter that will act as a intermediate between a simple customized table with data of things that relate to a specific customer. In the backend, there is a configuration that maps an user email with the customer that will be used. The backend itself is a OData service exposed through integration suite. This project was created with the CAP template in Business Application Studio. This part is working pretty much fine: i can access the instance of the CAP service with the approuter from a browser
  • I have a SAPUI5 application which has its own lifecycle, so it lives in a separate repository than the CAP microsservice. This application is hosted in SAP Build Workzone, standard edition, and the objective is to forward any request to the backend to the CAP Microssservice as a proxy to the backend that adds the user ID information (i.e., the email of the logged in user) seamlessly to retrieve data in the backend without the user even knowing that this is happening .

The CAP service works like a charm if I call the endpoint from the Browser:

And now, I want to be able to call this same endpoint from my SAPUi5 application that is hosted in SAP Build workzone. I have seen the documentation of Build Workzone  and went through some tutorials, but all of them shows the case when the UI is deployed altogether with the CAP service in the same repository, which unfortunately is not my case. 

I have went through a lot of blog posts and other questions that looked like a similar error was happening, but I had no luck in fixing so far.

 

Here's my understanding:

  • The CAP app has two service instances managed within its mta: gt-customer-portal-access-auth (technical name xsuaa, plan application) and gt-customer-portal-access-auth (technical name destination, plan lite). They are both binded to the approuter and to the CAP generated service, so it looks good
    below is the MTA of the CAP service:

    version: 1.0.0
    description: "A simple CAP project."
    parameters:
      enable-parallel-deployments: true
    build-parameters:
      before-all:
        - builder: custom
          commands:
            - npm ci
            - npx cds build --production
    modules:
      - name: gt-customer-portal-access-srv
        type: nodejs
        path: gen/srv
        parameters:
          instances: 1
          buildpack: nodejs_buildpack
        build-parameters:
          builder: npm-ci
        provides:
          - name: srv-api # required by consumers of CAP services (e.g. approuter)
            properties:
              srv-url: ${default-url}
        requires:
          - name: gt-customer-portal-access-auth
          - name: gt-customer-portal-access-destination

      - name: gt-customer-portal-access
        type: approuter.nodejs
        path: app/router
        parameters:
          keep-existing-routes: true
          disk-quota: 256M
          memory: 256M
        requires:
          - name: srv-api
            group: destinations

              name: srv-api # must be used in xs-app.json as well

              forwardAuthToken: true
          - name: gt-customer-portal-access-auth
          - name: gt-customer-portal-access-destination
        provides:
          - name: app-api
            properties:
              app-protocol: ${protocol}
              app-uri: ${default-uri}

    resources:
      - name: gt-customer-portal-access-auth
        type: org.cloudfoundry.managed-service
        parameters:
          service: xsuaa
          service-plan: application
          path: ./xs-security.json
          config:
            xsappname: gt-customer-portal-access-gt-br-${space}
            tenant-mode: dedicated
            oauth2-configuration:
              redirect-uris:
                - https://*~{app-api/app-uri}/**
        requires:
          - name: app-api
      - name: gt-customer-portal-access-destination
        type: org.cloudfoundry.managed-service
        parameters:
          service: destination
          service-plan: lite
    in xs-security.json, I have the following: 
    {
      "xsappname": "gt-customer-portal-access-gt-br-${space}",
      "tenant-mode": "dedicated",
      "oauth2-configuration" : {
        "grant-types" : [
          "authorization_code",
          "password",
          "client_credentials",
          "refresh_token",
          "user_token"
        ]

    and I have already assigned the UserRole to my User in BTP through a new Role Collection.

    in the approuter, I have the following:

    {
      "routes": [
        {
          "source": "^/(.*)$",
          "target": "$1",
          "destination": "srv-api",

  • In my SAPUI5 application, as per some of the documents i've gone through, I should bind the same XSUAA instance that is managed by the CAP Application. So the MTA of the UI5 application is as below (there are some comments as I was trying different approaches to know where exactly the problem could be). Below is the MTA.yaml file of the SAPUI5 app:

    # - Authentication: OAuth2UserTokenExchange
    # Name: comvendorcustomermaterialorigin_uaa
    # ServiceInstanceName: comvendorcustomermaterialorigin-xsuaa-service
    # ServiceKeyName: comvendorcustomermaterialorigin-uaa-key
    # sap.cloud.service: comvendorcustomermaterialorigin
    existing_destinations_policy: update

    - npm install
    - npm run build:cf

    parameters:

    Name: ui5
    ProxyType: Internet

    URL: https://ui5.sap.com
    - Authentication: NoAuthentication #setar a destination aqui n√£o seria necess√°rio se vc fizer dirteto no BTP. Por√©m, aparentemente √© uma boa pr√°tica fazer isso a partir
    #do mta
    Name: portal-clientes-credentials
    ProxyType: Internet
    Type: HTTP
    URL: https://fb031469trial-dev-get-user-email-saml.cfapps.us10-001.hana.ondemand.com
    #update abaixo: ap√≥s voltar o app no Workzone com 403 - ultima tentativa hoje _ 02:24 08/11/2024
    # - Authentication: OAuth2UserTokenExchange
    # Name: customer_Brasil_GT_CAP_BE
    # URL: https://fb031469trial-dev-gt-customer-portal-access.cfapps.us10-001.hana.ondemand.com

  • Note that it refers to the same xsuaa service as in gt-customer-portal-access-auth.

The problem is that when I open the app in build Workzone, the medatada call for the service returns 403 forbidden without even reaching the app router (I Believe so as there is no logs in the service instance, so it's a bit odd)

Note that i have added a call to the service "whoami" as a test service that is in the CAP application and it's returning 404, and if i uncomment this part of the MTA and redeploy:

  • # - Authentication: OAuth2UserTokenExchange
    # Name: customer_Brasil_GT_CAP_BE
    # URL: https://fb031469trial-dev-gt-customer-portal-access.cfapps.us10-001.hana.ondemand.com
    # Type: HTTP
    # ProxyType: Internet
    # forwardAuthToken: true
    # existing_destinations_policy: update

it also returns 403 now:

I am not sure exactly what needs to be done either in CAP or in the SAPUI5 setup, as it looks like the CAP setup is OK, and most of the documents/blogs says that a destination in BTP level should be enough for the Build workzone approuter to connect to the CAP service. I have this destination setup as below:

Does anyone have gone a similar requirement and managed to make it work? I'm thinking that the approuter generated with my cap app can be the culprit but i'm not sure.

I also checked mostly the capire documents (which always uses the samples of UI5 along with CAP at the same deployment) and the documentation of Build Workzone (mainly https://help.sap.com/docs/build-work-zone-standard-edition/sap-build-work-zone-standard-edition/developing-html5-applications-and-extensions?locale=en-US and other related topics), but I still had no luck on making it work. There is also a sample in https://github.com/SAP-samples/cap-sflight but it uses an approuter from the SAPUI5, which I understood that is not the case when deployng the application to SAP Build Workzone, standard edition (looks like it has its own approuter).

Really appreciate any inputs,

Erick Grilo.

entry.title: Second Half 2025 Release: The Latest Enhancements in SAP SuccessFactors Learning
entry.content:
The second half 2025 release brings a host of new enhancements across the entire SAP SuccessFactors HCM portfolio. In this blog, we'll discuss the key highlights of what we are delivering for the SAP SuccessFactors Learning solution. As always, if you are eager for more, be sure to check out the ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs New Viewer‚Äô. 

Manager view enhancements:

Building on the innovations rolled out in both the 2H 2024 and 1H 2025 releases, we are excited to announce additional enhancements to the manager view. Managers will now be able to manage admin assignment due dates, based on configuration, to allow managers who are in charge of their teams' training assignments to update specific due dates without additional admin intervention. This gives managers greater flexibility to adjust deadlines based on specific needs whether those items are part of a curricula or a free floating assignment. Manager experience has also been enhanced to allow for easier identification of team members by including the ID and organizational information of each employee and more seamless navigation of the team hierarchy view. 

Manager due date change

iContent Management Tool rollout:

iContent Management is a new system tool that allows admins to view and delete content stored in the iContent server, meaning it is no longer necessary to directly access the iContent server to view and delete content. Admins will also be able to view course affiliations of each stored content file and schedule content deletion and course cleanup, all from one tool. 

iContent Management tool admin page

Ongoing Enhancements     

As with every release, this is just a snippet of the enhancements and innovations we are delivering across Learning and the full SAP SuccessFactors HCM suite. For full details, please check out the 2H 2025 Release Highlights Resources: 

  • 2H 2025 Release Highlights Brochure
  • 2H 2025 Release Highlights Video 
  • 2H 2025 Release Highlights News Article 
  • Product Release & Road Map Information

Learn more about SAP SuccessFactors Learning.

entry.title: Re: 2H 2025 Release Highlights of SAP Best Practices for SAP SuccessFactors Time Management
entry.content:
Hello @bernardo_jas ,

thanks a lot for your feedback!

Please see below answers to your questions:

  • "Changes to Maternity Leave - is it not possible to make this available for other countries?"
    The rules/picklist/custom fields delivered here are for the concrete use case of maternity leave Germany. From a high-level perspective, it can be taken over for other countries where the behavior of maternity leave is similar, and adapted accordingly to fit to that country. If you have suggestions for a particular country, that is already in scope for Best Practices Time Management, please let us know. We would take it up based on priorities and capacity.
  • "The Time Statements were already available, right? It was already available in the system."
    Yes, the time statements were already available. We‚Äôve delivered them in the 1H 2025 release, but didn‚Äôt create a blog a that time. Therefore we mentioned them in the current blog.
  • "Regarding the control of the number of clockings/clockings. If the required number of clockings/clockings is not made, is there any way to deduct the value of x hours if those clockings/clockings are missing?"
    What do you mean by ‚ÄúNumber of clockings/clockings is not made‚Äù? Are they not made because the employee forgot to punch or because the employee is on leave? For the use case in which the employee forgot to punch, please refer to KBA: 3313903 - Report for missing Clock in and Clock Out - SAP for Me

Best regards,

Monica and Mohan

entry.title: Re: Can We Download App ID, Reference Information, and Ob...
entry.content:
Good day @byd 

Thank you for your question.

Answer to question 1 on available fields:

They are Document Type, Reference Document Number, Manual Entry Idicator,                                                                          Sources Process, Header Text and Line Item Text and Cost Center. See Display Journal Entries & Entry View for Line Item Display for more details.

Answer to question 2 on adding column:

The answer is yes. You need to enable the fields mentioned in question 1. Thereafter, you need to export them and include them in the file.  See App Extensibility: Display and Manage Journal Entries (Key User) & Display Line Items in General Ledger

Answer to question 3 on alternative app availability:

You should consider using the Journal Entry Analyzer, Manage Journal Entries, Display Document Flow and G/L Account Line Item Browser are alternatives you can consider. Have a look at Journal Entry Analyzer & Manage Journal Entry Templates

Answer to question 4 on workaround:

You can use the standard extensibility. You do not require any ABAP. You can either Use the Custom Analytical Query or use OData service for external reporting. The CDS Views, Journal Entry Item - Read (A2X), Custom Analytical Queries & Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: 3ZB Billing Cost between companies is not working
entry.content:
Good day @adrian321 

Thank you for your question.

You can consult the following references for further details.

Intercompany Billing, Communication Scenarios, How to configure output parameter determination, How to configure output parameter determination for purchase contracts, Set Up Output Parameter Determination for Purchase Order & AIF Monitoring.

To summarise, 3ZB relies on plant-level data for intercompany services valuation and on the SAP_COM_0109 communication scenario for automatic document replication in public cloud. Once you add the plant & Accounting data to the service material, and confirm the intercompany communication and BBP mappings, the purchase order will trigger an EDI message that creates the sales order in the supply ing company. Which then completes the 3ZB process.

Below is a step-by-step guidance:

 First you need to verify your communication arrangement. Open th Communication Arrangements app, ensure SAP_COM_0109 is active in both inbound and outbound tenants.

Make sure the communication user and endpoint URL are correctly paired. Both should be active.

Next step is to check the output parameter determination to ensure your Output type PURCHASING_ORDER is verified. Ensure channel is EDI, Receiver= Supplying company‚Äôs BP and form template = YY1_MM_PURCHASE ORDER (as shown in your screenshot). Then confirm the condition-based trigger aligns with your intercompany setup.

Thereafter, validate your Business Partner Setup. For this open the Maintain Business Partner app, each company must be set up as both supplier and customer of the other. Make sure both have valid Sales Area and Purchasing Org data. Make sure the customer and supplier numbers should be cross-referenced correctly.

 Finally, you need to review the message dashboard in the supplying tenant. Open the Manage Dashboard- SAP Application Interface Framework App. Ensure you filter by the Namespace (/INTERCOMPANY), Status (All) and date set to today.

If you don‚Äôt find any inboud message, then it wasn‚Äôt received which points at a communication issue. If it exists but failed, check the XML payload and partner for errors.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Migrating SAP PI/PO XI Proxy scenarios to Integration Suite ‚Äì Key considerations and recommendations
entry.content:
With the recent features in SAP Integration Suite‚Äîsuch as the ability to migrate Service Interfaces from SAP PI/PO to Cloud Integration and the introduction of the pipeline concept, the topic of migrating XI Proxies to Integration Suite has gained fresh significance. If you‚Äôve been waiting for the right moment to move your proxy-based integrations, this might just be it. The following sections outline key considerations and practical recommendations for a smooth and future-ready transition.

A) Modernize While You Migrate

While SAP supports the migration of legacy protocols such as Proxy, helping customers preserve their existing investments, it‚Äôs also a good time to consider modernization. Move away from older or proprietary interfaces toward modern, cloud-native, and interoperable options like SOAP or OData services to ensure long-term stability and easier evolution of your integration landscape.

B) Leverage SAP provided Accelerators

Before you start rebuilding interfaces from scratch, explore what SAP already provides out-of-the-box, from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

  • Prepackaged Integration Content: SAP Integration Suite pre-built content can significantly accelerate migration by making use of pre-delivered integration flows, script collections, etc., spanning across key end-to-end business processes, cutting across your SAP and non-SAP systems.
  • Standard APIs and Events: Consume standard APIs and business events available for your SAP S/4HANA edition to avoid / reduce customization and thus keep the core clean.

C) Migrating ESR Proxy Objects to Integration Suite

In the ECC ‚Äì PI/PO landscape, the Enterprise Services Repository (ESR) served as the central design-time hub for maintaining and versioning proxy schemas and interface definitions. This enabled the well-established ‚Äúoutside-in‚Äù development model, where integration developers first defined the structure in middleware via Data type, Message type and Service Interface, after which ABAPers implemented the Proxy class/method in the backend.

When SAP Integration Suite was first introduced, it lacked an ESR-equivalent capability to host and manage proxy schemas. Consequently, one option for customers was to keep their PI/PO ESR systems running to maintain these schemas, regenerate proxies in S/4HANA, and then use Integration Suite iflows for execution.

Additionally, SAP also introduced the Metadata Repository in S/4HANA, allowing schemas to be maintained directly within the backend (via the transaction SPXNMIG)‚Äîremoving the dependency on ESR. However, this represented a shift from the earlier outside-in model to a more backend-driven (‚Äúinside-out‚Äù) approach.

With the new feature released in Q3 2025 allowing migration of Service Interface objects from ESR to Integration Suite, it‚Äôs now possible to manage proxy schemas directly within Integration Suite‚Äîjust as you did in PI/PO. This advancement removes the need to depend on S/4HANA‚Äôs metadata repository or continue operating ESR purely for schema governance. It reintroduces the familiar outside-in development model, allowing interface definitions to remain in the integration layer.

Please also read this blog post, for additional details on proxy generation based on Service Interface migrated to Integration Suite.

This step of migrating your Service Interface object from SAP PI/PO is optional, and you need it only if you want to continue maintaining or modifying the proxy schema in the future. Otherwise, you can proceed directly with migrating runtime artifacts via the migration tooling guided wizard (discussed in the next section below).

D) Migrating Proxy-Based Scenarios (Deployable Components)

While we focused earlier on moving design-time definitions such as Service Interfaces (SI) and Message Types (MT), this step deals with the deployable components that enable actual message processing in Integration Suite.

To clarify the distinction ‚Äî the Service Interface you migrated in the previous step is not deployed in the Integration Suite tenant. It remains as a repository artifact, referenced by the backend system via SPROXY for proxy generation and linkage at runtime. Its purpose ends there. If, at any point in the future, you need to enhance or extend the schema, you would do so by editing the underlying Message Type that the Service Interface references.

In this step, we focus on migrating the ICO objects as iflows ‚Äî the deployable components responsible for message execution during runtime.

You can use the migration tooling to convert your existing XI proxy-based configurations into equivalent iflows. Depending on your Migration strategy, you can choose between standard approach or pipeline approach. The pipeline approach offers several operational benefits, such as reduced number of JMS queues, artifact reuse, simplified operations with clearly separated error queues, sophisticated restart mechanisms and Exactly Once message processing ‚Äì to name a few. Especially for Proxy-based scenarios, the pipeline concept helps in Reliable message processing, decoupling, common entry point for inbound scenarios (as described in the next section). Given these advantages, we recommend that you consider and apply the pipeline concept to migrate your Proxy based scenarios to Integration Suite. Read more about the Pipeline concept in this blog post.

E) Establishing a Common Entry Point

Establish a common entry point for all inbound XI Proxy messages either by modelling your own generic inbound iflow for XI, or leveraging the out-of-the-box generic XI inbound iflow that comes as part of the pipeline concept. The common entry point mirrors the Generic XI Sender Channel setup you may recall from SAP PI/PO. The generic XI inbound iflow, shipped as part of the generic pipeline package is impressively versatile‚Äîit can handle all QoS (Exactly Once, Exactly Once in Order, and Best Effort) without additional development or configuration effort. That‚Äôs yet another strong reason to choose the pipeline approach.

F) Configuring a Single Destination

As a corollary of setting up a common entry-point iflow, only one HTTP destination is required from your SAP S/4HANA system‚Äîpointing to this generic inbound iflow. This simplifies connectivity setup and minimizes administrative overhead.

G) Sender/Receiver-Specific Queues and Federated Landscape Design in Pipeline-Based Proxy Migrations

In this section, we‚Äôll discuss two aspects that could come into play at the intersection of XI Proxy migration and the pipeline concept in SAP Integration Suite:

1) Defining Sender/Receiver-Specific Queues
In classic SAP PI/PO, message monitoring could be conveniently filtered by Communication Component, giving operations team a clear view of message traffic per backend system. While Integration Suite does not mirror this behaviour directly, a similar outcome can be achieved within the pipeline setup by defining sender- or receiver-specific JMS queues. This approach allows message segregation per system, targeted retries, and operational isolation without interfering with other integrations. More details on configuring sender / receiver specific JMS queues for pipeline can be found in this Help portal page.

2) setting up separate pipelines for federated landscapes
Many enterprises historically operated multiple ABAP backends‚Äîsuch as Finance, SRM, or CRM‚Äîsupported by distinct PI/PO systems aligned by Line of Business (LoB) or regional boundaries. As these organizations move toward Integration Suite modernization and consolidate middleware into a single tenant, it remains important to retain autonomy and governance separation across business domains.

The pipeline approach enables this by allowing you to replicate the standard pipeline package into individual design workspaces‚Äîone per LoB or region‚Äîsupported by consistent artifact naming conventions and Access Policies that control visibility and ownership. This setup helps balance consolidation with distributed control, ensuring each domain can manage its proxy-based integration flows independently.
With this rationale in mind, SAP has published the New Integration Packages for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration.

This model preserves the federated operating style of large enterprises while streamlining governance, monitoring, and operations within a single, cloud-native Integration Suite tenant.

While the considerations in this section‚Äîqueue separation and federated pipelines‚Äîare applicable to other interface types and protocols as well, they are highlighted here because proxy-based interfaces typically form a significant portion of many organizations‚Äô legacy landscape. Addressing these design aspects as part of proxy migration ensures that modernization efforts not only move interfaces to the cloud but also align with scalable, operationally sustainable integration practices suited for the long term.

Most PI/PO systems carry a large footprint of Proxy interfaces. Migrating them to Integration Suite is not just about tool-based conversion but about adopting patterns that keep the setup clean and maintainable in the long run. With the right approach in place, the transition becomes less of a migration task and more of a steady move toward a simplified, future-ready integration landscape.

entry.title: 2H 2025 Release Highlights: New innovations in SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding
entry.content:
With the 2H 2025 release, we have delivered new capabilities within SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding to improve how organizations attract and hire the best talent.  

Through customer influence on the Customer Community and innovative product enhancements, we are bringing your ideas to life and driving improvements across the recruiting experience.

To learn more watch the on-demand Q&A webinars: 2H 2025 Product Release Webinars and Recruiting & Onboarding 2H 2025 Customer Release Q&A. To hear more about the roadmap and broader view of our strategy, watch the VIP Virtual Program for Strategic Roadmap Updates.    

All of the 2H 2025 release items can be found on the What‚Äôs New Viewer. These new features will be live in Production on November 16th, 2025.

This release brings enhanced AI-driven capabilities to the SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding solution, enabling hiring teams to streamline key onboarding activities, improve offboarding, and accelerate hiring.

Auto-completion of new hire activities

With auto-completion of new hire activities, administrators can now automate routine onboarding tasks, administrators can now automate routine onboarding tasks, like preparing for day one and writing welcome messages. This saves time in high-volume and bulk hiring scenarios, ensures consistency, and lets hiring managers and new hires focus on a successful start.

AI-assisted document processing

AI-assisted document processing further enhances onboarding by automatically extracting information from IDs and passports to support employee verification, ensuring compliance while reducing manual input.

Redesigned offboarding dashboard

The redesigned offboarding dashboard provides a clear, unified view for HR and hiring manager to track progress, minimize delays, and deliver a smooth transition from employee to alumni.

SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) for Onboarding

A new embedded extensibility wizard feature from SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) is now available within Onboarding. This powerful tool guides users through creating custom application extensions, such as adding unique data fields or tailoring business processes. By simplifying customization, the extensibility wizard helps customers quickly add the fields and workflows they need to reduce time spent on manual updates and make it easier to complete tasks accurately.

Continuously Delivering Enhancements     

With every release, we are excited to deliver these new innovations and continue our journey of providing even greater value to our customers. For full details, please check out the 2H 2025 Release Highlights Resources: 

  • 2H 2025 Release Highlights Brochure
  • 2H 2025 Release Highlights Video 
  • 2H 2025 Release Highlights News Article  
  • Product Release & Road Map Information

Learn more about SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding.

entry.title: Re: Emission Factors on SAP Sustainability Control Tower
entry.content:
SAP provides default emission factor data that includes the following data packages from the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA):

  • EPA-2023
  • EPA-2023-Spend
  • EPA-2024

These packages contain emission factors for Scope 1 ‚Äì Stationary combustion, Scope 2 ‚Äì Purchased electricity, steam, and heat, and Scope 3 - Waste Generated in Operations and End-of-Life Treatment of Sold Products. Users can access this information in the Manage Emission Factors app itself and export the data packages via Excel file or refer to the Using Data Published by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency guide for more details.

For additional government-provided emission factor data, please consult the Using Default Emission Factor Data guide.

entry.title: Bring your own Hugging Face Transformers in SAP AI Foundation
entry.content:
üåüIntroduction

At SAP TechEd 2025, I demonstrated how to operationalize Hugging Face Transformer models in SAP AI Foundation using the Bring Your Own Model (BYOM) approach.

The goal was to show how I can move beyond consuming pre-hosted APIs and instead own the full model lifecycle ‚Äì from training to serving inside SAP BTP.

My showcase focused on blocked invoice classification in SAP S/4HANA, a common process bottleneck.

Using BYOM, I trained and deployed a custom NLP model that predicts why an invoice was blocked, helping finance teams accelerate processing and reduce manual work.

üîçWhy BYOM Matters

BYOM enables organizations and developers to:

  • Train, deploy, and govern their own models rather than relying on third-party APIs.
  • Maintain full control of data, model weights, and compliance.
  • Reuse open-source innovation (such as Hugging Face Transformers) within the secure boundaries of SAP BTP.
  • Adapt models continuously to evolving business data without vendor lock-in.

This approach contrasts with SAP‚Äôs Generative AI Hub, where models are pre-hosted by SAP or partners and accessed via API only.

With BYOM, I define the model architecture, container image, and YAML-based orchestration.

SAP AI Core executes these workflows securely, while AI Launchpad provides lifecycle management, logging, and governance.

üß† Use Case: Blocked Invoice Classification

Invoices in SAP S/4HANA can be blocked for reasons such as mismatched quantities, missing purchase orders, or pricing errors.

To automate this review, I fine-tuned a DeBERTa-v3-base model from Hugging Face on labeled invoice text.

Label map:

Label Category

0Price Variance
1Quantity Mismatch
2Missing PO Reference
3Three-Way Match Failure
4Supplier Issues

‚öôÔ∏èBYOM Architecture in SAP AI Foundation

The BYOM setup in SAP AI Core uses modular components that I can fully customize and version-control.

 

This architecture allows me to deploy, retrain, and scale models independently while maintaining full ownership of data and artifacts.

üß© End-to-End BYOM Flow

Below is a visual representation of the Bring Your Own Model workflow that connects all components:

This diagram illustrates how:

  • The GitHub repository stores YAML templates (training-template.yaml, serving-template.yaml) and runtime configurations that sync with AI Core.
  • AI Core executes deployments using Docker images stored in the Docker Registry.
  • The KServe InferenceService (FastAPI) runs inside AI Core and is consumed by CAP or Fiori applications.
  • SAP AI Launchpad provides a single interface for monitoring, versioning, and managing deployments.

üß≠ Preparing SAP AI Core for BYOM

Before deploying the model, I performed several key setup steps to prepare SAP AI Core and AI Launchpad for BYOM:

  1. Create AI Core and AI Launchpad Instances ‚Äì provisioned both services on SAP BTP for orchestration and lifecycle management.
  2. Create a Resource Group ‚Äì isolated compute and storage resources for this project.
  3. Set Up Docker Registry Connection ‚Äì linked my private registry and created a secret (docker-registry-secret).
  4. Onboard the GitHub Repository ‚Äì connected the repo to AI Core so YAML templates stay in sync with AI Launchpad.
  5. Register Datasets and Model Artifacts ‚Äì uploaded CSVs and defined output artifact paths.
  6. Create API Client ‚Äì generated credentials for pipeline execution.
  7. Validate Configuration ‚Äì ran a quick smoke test to confirm all mounts, secrets, and permissions were functional.

 

 

This one-time configuration ensures a seamless transition between local development and enterprise-grade orchestration in AI Core.

üß© Training Pipeline (Bring Your Own Training Logic)

I created a training template (training-template.yaml) that runs my PyTorch script inside AI Core:

apiVersion: argoproj.io/v1alpha1
kind: WorkflowTemplate
metadata:
  name: invoice-classifier-training
spec:
  arguments:
    parameters:
      - name: trainImage
        value: "docker.io/itsmarlo/invoice-train:latest"
      - name: baseModel
        value: "microsoft/deberta-v3-base"
      - name: numLabels
        value: "5"

The workflow fine-tunes the model, evaluates it, and stores the trained weights as an artifact.

All training logic, hyperparameters, and dependencies are defined by me, illustrating the ‚Äúbring your own‚Äù principle in action.

Training dependencies (requirements-train.txt)

torch==2.3.1
transformers>=4.42.0
datasets>=2.20.0
scikit-learn>=1.4.2
pandas>=2.2.2

üß† Serving Pipeline (Bring Your Own Inference Service)

The serving template (serving-template.yaml) deploys the model as a REST API using a lightweight FastAPI application:

apiVersion: ai.sap.com/v1alpha1
kind: ServingTemplate
metadata:
  name: invoice-classifier-serving
spec:
  parameters:
    - name: image
      default: "docker.io/itsmarlo/invoice-serve:latest"
    - name: port
      default: 8080

Serving stack (requirements-serve.txt)

fastapi>=0.111.0
uvicorn[standard]>=0.30.0
torch==2.3.1
transformers>=4.42.0
pydantic>=2.7.0

AI Core hosts this container as a KServe inference service that scales automatically and can be consumed securely by any SAP application.

üßæ Testing the BYOM Deployment

I validated the deployed endpoint directly from AI Launchpad and Postman:

curl -X POST "https://<aicore-endpoint>/v1/invocations" \\
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \\
  -d '{"text":"Invoice blocked due to mismatch between PO and invoice quantity"}'

Response:

{
 "predicted_label": "Quantity Mismatch",
 "confidence": 0.94
}

üß© Integration into SAP Applications

I integrated the inference endpoint with:

  • SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) for data exchange
  • SAP CAP services calling the AI Core endpoint
  • Fiori Elements UI showing predictions in blocked-invoice apps

This completes the BYOM loop ‚Äì training in AI Core, serving through KServe, and consuming predictions in SAP S/4HANA.

üí°Key Insights from Building a BYOM Scenario

  • Validate locally first: Most deployment issues come from path or dependency errors.
  • Keep Docker architecture consistent: Always build for linux/amd64.
  • Version everything: YAMLs, images, and datasets must align.
  • Secure storage early: Validate S3 credentials and IAM roles.
  • Test endpoints before integration: Simple Postman tests save time.

Each step underlines the strength of BYOM: complete visibility and control of the AI lifecycle.

üìàResults

Metric Value

Base modelDeBERTa-v3-base
Training time‚âà 10 min (3 epochs, batch 16)
Model size‚âà 250 MB
Validation accuracy‚âà 90 %
Inference latency< 200 ms (CPU)

üî≠Next Steps

I plan to enhance the BYOM pipeline by:

  • Adding a metrics logging stage to AI Launchpad
  • Automating retraining with updated datasets
  • Integrating model explainability (SHAP, LIME)
  • Monitoring inference performance in real time

üß™ Try It Yourself

You can explore the full setup, including all YAML templates, Dockerfiles, and sample datasets, in my public GitHub repository:

üëâGitHub ‚Äì teched25-BYOM-classifier

Clone the repo, adjust the dataset paths, and deploy your own BYOM workflow on SAP AI Core.

The repository includes:

  • Training and serving templates for AI Core
  • Dockerfiles for both training and serving containers
  • Python scripts for model fine-tuning and inference
  • Example datasets and label maps

This example is a starting point for deploying your own Hugging Face models in SAP AI Foundation with full lifecycle control.

‚ö†Ô∏èChallenges and How I Overcame Them

Challenge Resolution

Image pull failures due to architecture mismatch (ARM vs. x86)Rebuilt Docker images specifically for linux/amd64, ensuring compatibility with AI Core runtimes.
Path mismatches and missing dependenciesValidated Docker builds locally before pushing to Docker Hub; used absolute paths for mounted datasets in YAML templates.
Dataset access issues (S3 permissions)Adjusted IAM policy and verified bucket configuration early in the setup.
Versioning conflicts between Docker images and YAML definitionsImplemented strict version tagging across all artifacts to maintain reproducibility.
Debugging failed executionsUsed AI Launchpad logs extensively and added print statements in Python scripts to trace errors.

Each challenge reinforced the value of BYOM‚Äîhaving full transparency and ownership made it easier to troubleshoot, iterate, and optimize the overall AI lifecycle.

üôåConclusion

This project demonstrates how Bring Your Own Model (BYOM) empowers developers to run open-source models like Hugging Face Transformers within SAP AI Foundation under full enterprise governance.

By defining my own Docker images, YAML pipelines, and inference logic, I combined open innovation with SAP‚Äôs orchestration and compliance framework.

The result is an end-to-end, production-ready AI service for SAP S/4HANA that remains explainable, auditable, and reusable across use cases.

Follow me on SAP Community for more insights on BYOM, Hugging Face integration, and AI Core automation.ü§ó

entry.title: ASUG Tech Connect 2025 summary: vibe coding, UX innovation, and AI everywhere
entry.content:
ASUG Tech Connect 2025 in Louisville, Kentucky, delivered big on both technology and connection. From the opening keynote to the final session, there were many examples of how AI improves both developer and business user productivity. While all the generative AI technologies are revolutionary and potentially very disruptive to organizations that ignore their impact, it was great to see AI applied in a variety of ways from creating ABAP code to moving Z-transactions in a clean core methodology. In this post, I‚Äôll highlight a few important themes, along with several moments at ASUG Tech Connect that made an impact on me. In each section, I‚Äôll provide some questions for you to discuss with your team.

ABAP is still going strong

The session ‚ÄúExtensibility with ABAP Cloud and AI in SAP Cloud ERP‚Äù says it all. Jens and Raghavendra  showed that ABAP has new generative AI tools that you can use to extend standard SAP Fiori apps and build new custom apps. With so many customers still contemplating their journey to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the ability to use familiar skills makes it easier to transition.

AI-powered features make SAP Cloud ERP even easier to use

In ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs Next: AI-First Innovations in SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Suite‚Äù, Ullas and I showed several new embedded features to boost business users‚Äô productivity, most of which were powered by AI. Demos included a mix of released functionality, features in beta, and even a sneak preview of something from our lab. We received lots of great feedback on how people plan to use smart helpers if we bring this to market.

My Home for SAP S/4HANA

SAP Fiori elements apps

  • AI-assisted enterprise search
  • AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for insights cards
  • AI-assisted smart solutions for situations in My Home
  • Recap
  • Joule
  • AI-assisted easy filter
  • AI-assisted smart summarization
  • AI-assisted easy fill
  • AI-assisted error explanation
  • Smart Helpers (working name ‚Äì sneak preview)

Ask yourself:

  • Do your business users still spend too much time on manual navigation?
  • Could a smart home screen or conversational interface drastically reduce that?
  • What is holding you back from adopting AI in your organization?

No-code, low-code, and pro-code are converging with vibe coding

In ‚ÄúUsing Generative AI to Accelerate SAP Fiori App Development‚Äù Ullas demonstrated how code-generation, conversational interfaces, and tooling changes are altering how we build apps. Using VS Code and Cline, connected to an SAP back end, he created a fully functional app, including CAP service and sample data, using only text prompts ‚Äì no coding at all. He started the app creation process by loading an image of what he wanted, then added functionality by asking Cline to build it. When error messages came up, he pasted screen shots back into the tool and asked it to fix the error. This can reduce the time to create a first prototype from weeks to hours. Skilled developers are required for making sure the app is production worthy, testing, and putting into production. We had some customers share their experience using coding agents and appreciation for how SAP packaged this to simplify the process. Some plan to expand their efforts on this journey and potentially share their stories in next year‚Äôs ASUG Tech Connect or SAP TechEd.

Ask yourself:

  • How much more AI can you use to accelerate development?
  • What would you need to see to gain confidence that you can use it for building apps?
  • Can you rebuild some of your old customizations in a clean core way to make your IT environment more agile?

SAP Fiori is essential to capture the full value of your SAP Cloud ERP implementation

My session on ‚ÄúCreating better user experiences with AI-powered SAP Fiori apps‚Äù discussed how SAP Fiori is a critical part of generating value from using SAP S/4HANA. Most of the audience had some Fiori experience and most were using AI in some way in their organization in some way.

 

The session started with the origins of Fiori and highlighted the huge leap in usability from the old SAP GUI screens to the intuitive, agile, and intelligent UX that My Home and SAP Fiori apps provide. It included a demo of many of the UX innovations in SAP Cloud ERP today, and discussion of how to get started with Fiori in your organization.

View slides from ‚ÄúCreating better user experiences with AI-powered SAP Fiori apps‚Äù session.

The main message was to get started now on your UX transformation now to provide your employees with a better user experience and access to AI-assisted capabilities that are built int SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Ask yourself:

  • What is holding us back from using more Fiori in the organization? Is it resistance from the users themselves, IT, or the business owners?
  • How do we quantify the business value of SAP Fiori in terms of higher user productivity, better data quality, lower training costs, and reduced cost of making changes to screens?

Clean core is necessary for digital transformation

The topic of clean core, meaning minimizing customizations to the SAP S/4HANA environment, was reinforced everywhere. The hand-on sessions ‚ÄúBuild On-Stack Extensions with ABAP Cloud in SAP Cloud ERP‚Äù and ‚ÄúModernize Classic Extensions for Clean Core‚Äù emphasized how you can use clean core principles and still build customizations to fit your business‚Äôs unique needs. Andre, Nora, and Ullas explained how to do this and guided people through practical exercises.

Ask yourself:

  • How much customization do you need to run your business? (Less is more!)
  • Can you use standard apps for more processes than you are doing today?
  • What is the cost of maintaining your custom code and how much is custom code preventing you from adopting the latest SAP ERP versions?

You don‚Äôt have to move to SAP Cloud ERP on your own

With such a broad collection of industries represented at ASUG Tech Connect, it was easy to find someone who had already solved the challenges you are facing. That‚Äôs the whole point of attending a large networking event like this ‚Äì to connect with like-minded individuals who want to move forward and need a little help (or push). I was fortunate to have many interesting breakfast, lunch, and break conversations about where people are struggling with moving their users to SAP Fiori apps.

The colleagues from Naturipe Farms, Brian and Dario, shared some of their experiences in ‚ÄúCustomer Show and Tell: From CDS View to Fiori Launchpad: Full-Stack Development with Eclipse ADT with Naturipe.‚Äù It was the third year in a row that they are presenting, so it‚Äôs great to follow their progress. Next year they plan to share their progress with a vibe-coding approach.

Ask yourself:

  • What communities can you join to learn from peers? ASUG, SAP Fiori development roundtable?
  • What thought leaders do you follow on LinkedIn that you can learn from?

There is no technology change without people change

It‚Äôs always the ‚Äúsoft skills‚Äù sessions that surprise me at SAP events with the lasting impact they make. Perhaps this is because the fundamental principles don‚Äôt change from year to year with new technology innovations, so they generally have more staying power. The panel on ‚ÄúLeading change in the age of AI: driving digital transformation through emotionally intelligent communication‚Äù had many great insights for business and technology leaders who are steering their organizations through the massive changes that an SAP S/4HANA upgrade, SAP Fiori implementation, or AI adoption brings. Some key takeaways included: focusing on business outcomes and ensuring that people can grow from the changes.

Ask yourself:

  • How can I empower my people by asking them: What are you good at? What do you want? What do you need? What do you fear? This will help you preempt many objections that are rooted in these issues.
  • What happens to my organization if we do nothing?

Get comfortable being uncomfortable

This is a time of rapid change for enterprise software and business in general. The AI tools have frequent updates in which their capabilities improve in some areas and don‚Äôt in others. It‚Äôs hard to keep up with all this, but critical. Nvidia CEO, Jensen Huang says ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not going to lose your job to AI. You‚Äôre going to lose your job to someone who uses AI.‚Äù Change is a part of progress; get used to it.

Ask yourself:

  • What new AI-related skills have you learned in the next month?
  • Where can you try some AI in your business that will allow you to learn with low risk?

Next steps:

  • Review the slides, which are available to attendees on the ASUG Tech Connect website.
  • Start exploring AI tools for development now. Even if you are not ready to incorporate them into your core business processes, you need to gain experience using them if you want to stay relevant in the industry.
  • Identify two use cases where AI can make a measurable business impact. Build a proof of concept in your test environment or sandbox system to measure the return on investment.
  • Follow the speakers of sessions that you liked on LinkedIn. You will gain insights into what they are working on and likely see innovations as soon as they become available.
  • Subscribe to our SAP Fiori development newsletter, where will share new innovations for application development as soon as they are available.

entry.title: How to use reserved words as property names in your OData service?
entry.content:
Introduction

Sometimes

there is the requirement to use field names that are reserved words such as Number, Begin or other reserved words as a propery property name of your OData service, e.g. to fill the value of a dynamic tile.

Implementation

When trying to set this name as an alias in your CDS view this fails with the error message: 

NUMBER is a reserved word (choose another field name) .

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Products'

define view entity ZI_VH_PRODUCT
  as select from zproducts
{
  key product       as Product,
      producttext   as Producttext,
      productgroup  as ProductGroup,
      price         as Price,
      currency      as Currency,
      baseunit      as BaseUnit,
      numberinstock as Number
}

Solution

Using the annotation @odata.property.name this can be achieved for RAP based OData services.

In the CDS view that is used by your OData service it is possible to add the following annotation

@odata.property.name: 'Number'

to the source code of the CDS view.   

This way the name of the CDS view property can be such that it does comply to the validations of the CDS editor, but at the same time the name of this field in the OData Service would be set to Number.

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Test'
@ObjectModel.query.implementedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_VH_PRODUCTS'

define view entity ZI_VH_PRODUCT
  as select from zproducts
{
  key product       as Product,
      producttext   as Producttext,
      productgroup  as ProductGroup,
      price         as Price,
      currency      as Currency,
      baseunit      as BaseUnit,
      @odata.property.name: 'Number'
      numberinstock as NumberInStock
}

As a result you will get the following result in the $metadata call.

<EntityType Name="Product2Type">
<Key>
<PropertyRef Name="Product"/>
</Key>
<Property Name="Product" Type="Edm.String" Nullable="false" MaxLength="40"/>
<Property Name="Producttext" Type="Edm.String" Nullable="false" MaxLength="40"/>
<Property Name="ProductGroup" Type="Edm.String" Nullable="false" MaxLength="40"/>
<Property Name="Price" Type="Edm.Decimal" Nullable="false" Precision="15" Scale="variable"/>
<Property Name="Currency" Type="Edm.String" Nullable="false" MaxLength="5"/>
<Property Name="BaseUnit" Type="Edm.String" Nullable="false" MaxLength="3"/>
<Property Name="Number" Type="Edm.String" Nullable="false" MaxLength="3"/>
</EntityType>

Also the Fiori Elements Preview shows the wished result:
